Problem:
Consider the linear time-invariant system governed by the differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\), where D is a constant matrix. Assess the effects of transforming the system with the operator \\( T(x) = Mx + N \\), where M and N are matrices and N is not necessarily zero.

If \\( T(x) \\) is applied to a vector \\( x_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\) without further intervention, will \\( x(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( x_0 \\) was evolved directly under \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\( T(x) \\) modifies the initial condition \\( x_0 \\) to \\( Mx_0 + N \\), impacting the trajectory of \\( x(t) \\). Since \\( N \\) adds a constant shift, the path and final state of \\( x(t) \\) at time T will differ unless \\( M \\) and \\( N \\) are specially configured relative to D.
